review.title: HISTORICAL REVIEW
review.paragraph1: The Rumiñahui canton originally was part of the Metropolitan District of Quito, being considered as a parish.
review.paragraph2: However, on May 31, 1938, General Alberto Enríquez Gallo elevated the parish of Sangolquí to an autonomous canton.
review.paragraph3: Thus taking the name of a national hero, the indigenous Rumiñahui, who represented a symbol of courage for all Ecuadorians.
review.paragraph4: A group of people formed a civic committee that promoted the creation of Rumiñahui Canton. In this way, both men and women from Sangolquí and its surroundings achieved, 87 years ago, the cantonization of Rumiñahui.

elements.rumiñahui: Stone face, an emblematic figure with historical significance.

monuments.title: MAIN MONUMENTS
monuments.paragraph1: Its body is dressed in multicolored tones — green reflects the constant renewal of Mother Nature, black represents the earth, the solemnity of the sun is shown in yellow, orange, and gold; crimson symbolizes struggle, effort, war, and blood, while dark blue conveys energy and health.
monuments.paragraph2: Endara Crown captured in this monument the golden delicacy of the gods using the NAIF technique, recalling through this work the fertility of the Valle de los Chillos.
monuments.paragraph3: The artwork depicts a peasant who, during his rest, seeks water and seems unable to find it — a man seated, drinking from a pilche, almost licking it dry.
monuments.paragraph4: A central monolith that functions as a solar clock, honoring the ancestral traditions of the region connected to agricultural cycles. It represents solstices and equinoxes and serves as a symbolic attraction of the park.

data.ubi: Cotogchoa Parish is located in the southwest of Rumiñahui Canton.

limits.data2: Amaguaña and Tambillo Parishes of Mejía Canton

data.ubi: The rural parish of Rumipamba is located in Rumiñahui Canton, Pichincha Province, 15 kilometers from the city of Sangolquí.

data.ubi: It is located in Rumiñahui Canton, Pichincha Province, in the Valle de los Chillos, about 34 km southeast of Quito.
